Literature Review:
The study of arthropod and pathogen damage on fossil and modern plants provides critical insights into the evolution of herbivory on land. The functional feeding group–damage type system has been instrumental in transforming our understanding of these interactions, offering a framework for analyzing the complex relationships between plants and their herbivores over a 420-million-year history. This system categorizes herbivory into distinct types based on the nature of the damage inflicted on plant tissues, allowing for a detailed examination of both ancient and modern plant-herbivore interactions (Labandeira, 2007). 

The earliest evidence of herbivory is found in the fossil record, dating back to the Silurian period, approximately 420 million years ago. These early interactions were primarily between simple land plants and arthropods, marking the beginning of a complex evolutionary relationship (Labandeira, 1998). The Devonian period saw the emergence of more complex plant structures, which coincided with an increase in the diversity and complexity of herbivore interactions (Labandeira, 2006). This period is crucial for understanding the early emergence of herbivore associations on land plants, as it set the stage for the later expansion of herbivory on seed plants.

The Permian–Triassic ecological crisis, one of the most significant extinction events in Earth's history, had profound effects on herbivore diversity. This event led to the formation of new, biologically diverse herbivore communities, particularly on gymnosperms, which dominated the landscape during the Triassic period (Labandeira and Sepkoski, 1993). The subsequent diversification of angiosperms during the Cretaceous period marked another major shift in herbivory patterns. Angiosperms provided new niches and resources, leading to an explosion in herbivore diversity and complexity (Wilf et al., 2001).

The Cretaceous–Paleogene (K-Pg) extinction event further reshaped herbivore communities, as it led to the extinction of many plant and herbivore species. However, it also provided opportunities for the rapid diversification of surviving lineages, particularly angiosperms, which became the dominant plant group in the post-K-Pg world (Labandeira et al., 2002). The Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), a period of rapid global warming approximately 56 million years ago, also had significant impacts on herbivore communities. Studies have shown that this period was characterized by increased herbivory, likely due to the expansion of tropical and subtropical habitats (Currano et al., 2008).

Recent studies have focused on the effects of transient climate events and longer-term climate trends on herbivory. These studies provide valuable data for understanding how current global change might affect plant-herbivore interactions. For example, research has shown that herbivore community responses can vary significantly with latitude, altitude, and habitat, highlighting the importance of considering these factors in predictions of future ecological changes (Adams et al., 2010).

Ongoing paleoecological research continues to address several key themes, including the antiquity of modern plant-herbivore interactions, differential herbivory between ferns and angiosperms, and the origins of modern tropical forests. The expansion of databases containing a multitude of fossil specimens, improvements in sampling strategies, and the development of new analytical methods have all contributed to the rapid advancement of this field (Wilf and Labandeira, 1999). These advancements have enabled researchers to address conceptually stimulating ecological and evolutionary questions, providing new insights into the complex dynamics of plant-herbivore interactions over geological time scales.

In conclusion, the study of arthropod and pathogen damage on fossil and modern plants has significantly enhanced our understanding of the origins and evolution of herbivory on land. The functional feeding group–damage type system has been a key tool in this research, allowing for detailed analyses of plant-herbivore interactions across different time periods and ecological contexts. As the field continues to evolve, it promises to yield further insights into the intricate relationships between plants and their herbivores, both in the past and in the context of current and future global changes.
